Posts.Content: On 7/14/2009 mama59 wrote: Went to have a mammogram. the findings were There is a well circumscribed hypoechoic mass that contains some low level internal echoes. Most likely represents a debris filled cyst. a 6 month follow up ultrasound is recommended in order to ensure the stability of this finding. It's been 6 months go for the ultrasound Thursday. does anyone have any comments on this of being cancer. I'm a new member and would apprecate any emput. thanks I agree with Roseann and Joan L,  I am living because I knew my lump did not feel right eventhough all the doctors said it was not cancer.  Finally, a breast surgeon ordered a breast MRI.  It was stage 2 cancer, but I am in remission now and doing well.  I believe you need to explore any possibility that you might have this disease.  All the best to you. Ann
Posts.Title: cancer

Posts.Content: Hello everyone, Thanks to all who expressed concern and for the many prayers for me.  After fighting breast cancer for almost two years, and thinking I was out of the  woods, I discovered a lump in the other breast.  It was in the same area as the lump I had on the other side that was cancer.  I had surgery last Tuesday and Thursday  the test came back negative for cancer.   I am so grateful. Ann
Posts.Title: good news

Posts.Content: Hi,   In the case of breast cancer there may be too many copies of a cancer-causing gene gene called an oncogene.  This oncogene called HER2 is part of a family of genes called c-erbB-2 (otherwise known  as her-2-/neu).  I found this definition on the internet when I was diagnosised with HER2-positive breast cancer.  I have finished regular chemo and radiation treatments, and I am currently in treatments of an every three week drip of Herceptin (an antibody that targets my breast cancer).  I sent you a more involved definition, but my system shut down and was lost before I could post.  Hope this helps you.
Posts.Title: HER2

Posts.Content: On 9/12/2008 jobo66 wrote:   On 9/12/2008 cacann wrote: Hi,   In the case of breast cancer there may be too many copies of a cancer-causing gene gene called an oncogene.  This oncogene called HER2 is part of a family of genes called c-erbB-2 (otherwise known  as her-2-/neu).  I found this definition on the internet when I was diagnosised with HER2-positive breast cancer.  I have finished regular chemo and radiation treatments, and I am currently in treatments of an every three week drip of Herceptin (an antibody that targets my breast cancer).  I sent you a more involved definition, but my system shut down and was lost before I could post.  Hope this helps you.I thank you very much for this info,and will be very interested if you could send me a more involved definition, i finshed my radiation treatments about two months ago and now i'm taking aromasin.I had a pet scan which said so far all cell are clear, but this is something iwould like to discuss with my oncos. Hi, again,   I am sorry to reply so late, but was having some serious side effects from the medications I am taking.  I am a believer in there are always reasons why we do or do not do things.  Based on that, I wanted to tell you that you should talk to your occologist about this, because everyone is different.  I know for me personally, I was told initially that it was good I was Her2-positive, because there is a treatment for the type of tumor I have.  Then I found out that it was bad that I was Her2-positive, because my tumor would grow faster.  So, who knows.  I do know that if you produce to much female hormone that is basically why you are Her-2 positive. For me, the Her2-positve medication is working (herceptin).  I have some fatigue associated with the medicine, but I am also taking femara, which is causing me some hurtful joint pain with some swelling.  This is just one of the symptoms I am having.  Hope things are going well for you.  Thank God we are among the few that have a cure possible. Ann
Posts.Title: HER2

Posts.Content: On 9/12/2008 jobo66 wrote:   On 9/12/2008 cacann wrote: Hi,   In the case of breast cancer there may be too many copies of a cancer-causing gene gene called an oncogene.  This oncogene called HER2 is part of a family of genes called c-erbB-2 (otherwise known  as her-2-/neu).  I found this definition on the internet when I was diagnosised with HER2-positive breast cancer.  I have finished regular chemo and radiation treatments, and I am currently in treatments of an every three week drip of Herceptin (an antibody that targets my breast cancer).  I sent you a more involved definition, but my system shut down and was lost before I could post.  Hope this helps you.I thank you very much for this info,and will be very interested if you could send me a more involved definition, i finshed my radiation treatments about two months ago and now i'm taking aromasin.I had a pet scan which said so far all cell are clear, but this is something iwould like to discuss with my oncos. Hi, again,   I am sorry to reply so late, but was having some serious side effects from the medications I am taking.  I am a believer in there are always reasons why we do or do not do things.  Based on that, I wanted to tell you that you should talk to your occologist about this, because everyone is different.  I know for me personally, I was told initially that it was good I was Her2-positive, because there is a treatment for the type of tumor I have.  Then I found out that it was bad that I was Her2-positive, because my tumor would grow faster.  So, who knows.  I do know that if you produce to much female hormone that is basically why you are Her-2 positive. For me, the Her2-positve medication is working (herceptin).  I have some fatigue associated with the medicine, but I am also taking femara, which is causing me some hurtful joint pain with some swelling.  This is just one of the symptoms I am having.  Hope things are going well for you.  Thank God we are among the few that have a cure possible. Ann
Posts.Title: HER2

Posts.Content: On 5/13/2009 Daughter of Karen wrote: This is my first post.  I am sorry to be here but I just lost a friend to mel and so I take cancer very seriously.  Today my mother saw the Dr. she has 3 nodules in L breast and will go for high contrast MRI on Friday.  We are not in a large metro area and I am wondering if the Dr's/hospitals and care are sufficient or if we need to get her to NYC or Boston (both within 4 hours of where we live) for evaluation.  She is supposed to see a surgeon on Monday so I guess her Dr. suspects something... Thanks so much for any advice about how to handle these next few appointments.   Love and Light, DOK Hi DOK, Tre does give good advise. I live in a fairly small town, but I have some great doctors. I did consider going thirty minutes further away to have treatments, but I am glad I did not.  My regular doctor refered me to a breast surgeon for second opinon for a lump I had  when two doctors did not think it was anything.  A mamo and sonigram did not show suspicious area.  My breast surgeon had me do a breast MRI to just make sure it was not cancer as I had a sister that had breast cancer.  After the MRI did show suspicious area, a biopsy was done.  This could be the procedure they are following to make sure it is not cancer.  Good Luck! Ann
Posts.Title: Help Please question on Quality of Medical Advice

Posts.Content: On 1/10/2009 Terriet wrote: I am trying to get prepared for lumpectomy and radiation.  I currently wear a back closing underwire bra.  I dont' think that will be comfortable following the lumpectomy.  Does anyone have suggestions of a specific bra that worked well following lumpectomy?  Any other suggestions for things I will need during recovering and an idea on how long it takes to recover?  Trying to get an idea of how many days I can anticipate to take off work.  I'm sure alot of this depends on the extensiveness of the surgery and the individual.  But I would appreciate any suggestions.  Hi Terriet,  You may not need my input as you have gotten a few great responses.  I am on the large breast size and found the very soft stretch sports bras and sleeper bras worked the best for me.  It hurts to try to sleep without some support.  As I healed, I graduated to my regular bras (not underwires).  Be sure to do the exercises they tell you to do.  Helps a lot! Time off depends on your healing. cac
Posts.Title: Bra suggestions following lumpectomy

Posts.Content: I was diagnosised with Breast Cancer late November 2007.  I had two back to back surgeries with the placement of the port during the last surgery as we knew I was going to have chemo treatments.  I did not start the chemo until the middle of January, but was already having problems with the port.  The area felt sore and bruised, and when I would turn a certain way, it felt like a pin was sticking into my skin.  I mentioned to my Occologist doctor the port does not feel right.  He looked at it, and stated it is just a vial in a vial.   I did not ask any more questions as the removal of the port would be worse as the veins in my arms are impossible to get.  Some of the cancer nurses have had problems connecting the IV's to the port.  One nurse said the port was wobbly.    Is this pain normal?  The pain is tolerable and does not hurt all the time.  I notice it mostly at night.
Posts.Title: port installed hurts

Posts.Content: On 2/14/2008 laborerlady wrote: ive had a port in since 2005 ,i must tell you that it has never bothered me. sounds like somthing isnt right.  ask your dr to take a look. does it flush ok? i go every 4 to 6 weeks and have it flushed and have my blood work done. this is the only time it gets aliitle sore. there are though many different types of ports so i dont know what yours is but, if it bothers you be persistent and have it checked     laborerlady Thank you, and I will be persistent.
Posts.Title: port installed hurts

Posts.Content: On 10/15/2008 Leafyg wrote: Just really green at all of this....been with my sister everyday for 6mths now doing chemo and stuff...yesterday they done radiacal mastectomy on her right breast.  They said they could not get all of the cancer...it is too close to blood supply in her arm and is in lymph nodes.  Would like to know if anyone has any info about someone going thru this and what is the likelihood that she might get cancer somewhere else ....she is continuing chemo and radiation after she heals.  plz help....feeling lost here.  Thanks  Leafyg Keep your chin up.  Sometimes, it is as hard on the caretaker as it is on the person with cancer.  Each diagnosis is different, and there are different cancers.  Best advise I can give you is to not be shy when you go with your sister to her doctor.  Have a list of questions and make sure he or she answers all of them.  Try to keep your sister as positive as possible.  This will help to combat the cancer cells. You and your sister will be in my prayers. CAC
Posts.Title: Sister had radical mastectomy yesterday.

Posts.Content: I appreciate you taking the time to respond to my message.  I asked everyone I knew before posting this message, because I was very concerned that something was not right.  How ever, I did find out what the problem was.  It sounds like it is just the oposite of your problem, I have to much tissue and not enough muscle tissue to hold the port in place.  I have been using the numbing drug on the port before going in for lab or chemo treatments.  This has helped with the pain for that.  I also found out that the one nurse that hurt me when inserting the needle into the port should have had the knowledge to hold the port in place before inserting the needle.  The sticking pain is an undesolved stitch, we think. I am tracking my daily progress with this disease.  I had no idea that a person's whole life centers around breast cancer after surgery and while going through treatments.  My treatments are very aggressive.  I am on a two week chemo treatment with a series of shots to stimulate my white blood cells after chemo.  I wish you luck!
Posts.Title: port installed hurts

Posts.Content: On 9/1/2008 kah49 wrote: I have had stage 2 breast cancer, (small tumor but it had spread to lymph nodes), also her2 positive. i have finished chemo and radiation and am now 5 months into the herceptin treatments. I also had double mastectomy. I would like to hear from someone who has been diagnosed as being her2 positive, and has had the herceptin treatments. I guess i would just like to know that there is hope at the end of this journey. My dr says that my cure rate is at about 70 to 80 percent, but I read that sometimes the herceptin does not always work. Even though my cure rate is pretty high, I still get nervous, after reading some of the info on breast cancer. Maybe I should just quit reading so much, huh? ha ha Thank you for any info k I have been diagnosed with breast cancer stage 2 in December 2007.  I am also her2 positive.  I had about a third of my left breast removed and had a second surgery to remove the rest of the lymph nodes  in that area and under my arm as they found a small tumor on one of the lymph nodes under my arm after the first surgery.  I have been treated very agressively since January 2008 with 7 chemo treatments ( sceduled for 8, but could not tolerate the last one) and 34 radiation treatments.  I was given herceptin in smaller amounts during my regular chemo treatments.  Now, I go every three weeks for a two hour drip of herceptin along with a Femora chemo tablet daily.  However, I was told this herceptin can only be used by individuals that have a certain type of cancer and they have to be her2 positive.  I understand the herceptin actually targets and kills any of these tumor cancer cells in your body.   I have regular blood tests that will tell if I have this type of cancer cells in my body.  You might ask your doctor about that.  If you need it, I will find out the name of the test.  So far, so good!  I hear unbelievable survival stories at the cancer center I go to, even with stage four cancer.  I do know trying to keep a positve attitude is healing, but sometimes it is a struggle to keep positive.  Ten years ago, you and I might not have survived with this diagnosis.  Great strides have been made concerning breast cancer, and I am greatful and thankful to God.  I know I am going through this for a reason.  Hopefully, a really good reason.  Good luck to you and I hope this helps. A
Posts.Title: herceptin

Posts.Content: On 2/14/2008 laborerlady wrote: ive had a port in since 2005 ,i must tell you that it has never bothered me. sounds like somthing isnt right.  ask your dr to take a look. does it flush ok? i go every 4 to 6 weeks and have it flushed and have my blood work done. this is the only time it gets aliitle sore. there are though many different types of ports so i dont know what yours is but, if it bothers you be persistent and have it checked     laborerlady Thank you for your reply.  I made a new friend this past week that happens to be a registered nurse that works with cancer patients.  She looked at the port and said it looks like I have a stitch that has not disolved that is sticking me.  Also, she said my port is wobbly.  Which means, where it is inserted there is very little muscle mass to hold it in place and it moves around.  This causes some uncomfortable feelings when I turn over at night.  I had the technician hold it in place before inserting the needle for lab and chemo and it worked better. Thanks, again.
Posts.Title: port installed hurts

Posts.Content: On 2/19/2008 Beth29 wrote:   On 2/11/2008 cacann wrote: I was diagnosised with Breast Cancer late November 2007.  I had two back to back surgeries with the placement of the port during the last surgery as we knew I was going to have chemo treatments.  I did not start the chemo until the middle of January, but was already having problems with the port.  The area felt sore and bruised, and when I would turn a certain way, it felt like a pin was sticking into my skin.  I mentioned to my Occologist doctor the port does not feel right.  He looked at it, and stated it is just a vial in a vial.   I did not ask any more questions as the removal of the port would be worse as the veins in my arms are impossible to get.  Some of the cancer nurses have had problems connecting the IV's to the port.  One nurse said the port was wobbly.    Is this pain normal?  The pain is tolerable and does not hurt all the time.  I notice it mostly at night.   I've had a port for over 2 years for Stage IV Met Breast Cancer - I've never experienced what you're talking about - sometimes it's a little sore or slightly bruised right after treatment - but that's it.  Are the nurses getting a good return of blood when the access? The only nurse that had a problem with the saline or getting blood was the nurse that did not hold the port in place before inserting the line.  All the other nurses have not had a problem as long as they hold the port in place.  You know, the strange thing is I am not sore after chemo or lab treatments. It is more a pain than soreness.  If I shift my position, the pain my go away.  Thanks for your reply and I will ask the doctor, again.
Posts.Title: port installed hurts

Posts.Content: On 3/2/2009 beckbeck220 wrote: I'm wondering how possible it is to be misdiagnosed with fibrocystic breast disease instead of cancer?  I went and had an ultrasound and mammo done today and that's what the technician for both is saying.  They were both pessimistic to begin with even doing the tests.  First I had the u.s. and the tech for that was like, "looks like fibrocystic breasts to me, but I have to let the doc decide if you need a mammo".  The doc saw a few worrisome spots so I had a mammo as well.  The mammo tech said the same thing but added, "you're too young for this to be cancer, so I'm sure it's just fibrocystic."  She even went on to tell me I should cancel my appt with the breast surgeon because it would just be a waste of money.  Are these people just disregarding me because I'm only 27?  Should I still go to the surgeon and request a biopsy?  I'm so confused and just as worried as before I had these tests done!!  Thanks!! Hi, I am a little late as many have given you great advise.  I would not be sending you this message if I had not been persistant about a lump I found in one of my breasts.  I had a mammogram and a sonigram, and was told by the doctor that read them that it was nothing just tissue breaking down.  I was not satisified and told my regular doctor that I had a feeling something was not right.  He sent me to a breast surgeon, and I was told it was not anything, but because my sister's history of breast cancer she ordered an MRI.  I was told that all the doctor's were surprised that something had shown up, because it did not feel or look like breast cancer.  They scheduled a biopsy, even though, they did not think it was anything for me to be worried about.  Long story short, it was a very aggressive tumor that had spread into a lymph node.  I am doing well except for the aftermath of surgery, chemo and radiation.  My lesson is not to scare you, but to listen to yourself.  Sometimes, we know more about our body than other's do.  Ann
Posts.Title: misdiagnosis?!?!?!

Posts.Content: On 11/6/2008 zanney wrote: When I was first diagnosed with ER/PR breast cancer, by means of a biopsy on the 2 cm lump I had detected, an MRI showed one and possibly two smaller cancers in the same breast that had not been detected on  a mammogram or by physical examination.  Because I had uncontolled hypertension, I was informed that surgery would provide extra risk for me.  I had tried to see an oncologist but was tunable to get an appointment with any oncologist until I had the surgery. After three tries I found a surgeon who agrees that it was my choice to have the risky (to me) surgery and he agreed to make an appointment with an oncologist for further consultation. Good luck for me as this oncologist put me on Arimidex.  It has been four years with absolutely no side effects and best of all all according to a recent MRI there is no sign of the cancer I had previously.  I have seen a cardiologist and my blood pressure was determined to be part of a heart problem - and the blood pressure and the heart problems are now controlled by medication and I have been saved from a possibly deadly heart attack.  And both breasts are still intact. Why is this treatment not offered to all women hormone sensitive cancer? My experience leads me to believe the surgeons have more control of breast cancer treatment than they should.  All options should be available to patients along with the physicians personal opinions.  If a women is willing to pay for a consultation with an oncoligist she should be able to - before surgery.  I think patients should be given hard cold facts as well as options for treatment.   Dear Zanney, I would guess most people are in a state of shock when they are told they have breast cancer or any cancer for that matter.  It was a rush thing with me as I had a fast growing tumor and time was important.  I was told I did not have any other options.  Was your cancer invasive? I tried to get as much information as possible before my surgeries were done, but like you I was not getting answers to the questions I was asking.  My surgeries were done by "the best" in the area, but the majority of her answers  to my questions were, "It is what it is."  I was puzzled at this answer.  I found that many people experience different after effects during and after chemo that the doctors will tell you minimal until you call and complain about joint pains, sickness, fatigue and other problems.  I finally told my doctor I wanted to know everything when my body began to shut down during the original agressive chemo treatments.  The doctors do a great service to most of us, and I know that.  I would most certainly not be sending this if they had not rushed treatment for me.
Posts.Title: Arimidex as sole treatment for breast cancer

Posts.Content: On 10/17/2008 Echos wrote: Hi everyone... I know I'm new here and I hope i'm not being intrusive, but I heard about this movie, Living Proof, that will be on lifetime tv tomorrow night (the 18th) at 9pm. It’s a real touching true story based on the book Her-2, which if you don’t know is about the oncologist and researcher Dr. Dennis Slamon, and his struggle behind developing the drug Herceptin and getting it approved. As a result of his efforts thousands of lives have been saved. I think it will be a touching movie and I wanted to share it with everyone here. There is more information right here http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n0F__IfeUXg God Bless Thank you, I will be sure to watch.   CAC
Posts.Title: Her-2 Movie

Posts.Content: On 6/27/2005 Hazel wrote: My mom had breast cancer in 1983 and 1991--received mastectomy and chemo the first time, then mastectomy and radiation the second time. Now has a recurrence of breast cancer in the right breast, evidenced by a severe rash and lesions on the skin over the breast area. We saw the oncologist today, and he started her on Femara--she's 83 years old, with emphysema and chronic nausea already. What experiences have others had with Femara? Thanks. I have been on Femara for a year.  In the beginning, I experienced joint pain, weight gain and sleeping a lot.  I have invasive breast cancer and have had Chemo, radiation and herceptin drip.  I started on the Femara after my chemo finished in May 2007. Hope this helps, and good luck! Ann
Posts.Title: Femara Experiences

Posts.Content: On 2/1/2009 Gentile wrote: I had a  masectomy in 2007 radiation and chemotherapy.  I was off work for 18 months and am just trying to return.  As hard as the surgery and treatment has been I am having a harder time now.  The numbness in the my hands and feet, the pain from the Femera in my hands.  I almost feel more emotional now then I did before.  Has anyone else been through this, am I just being silly.  It is so hard to talk to friends and family. As supportive as they are they just want to know that you are okay.  I have joined a gym, my diet is completely changed, I take supplements and read as many positive books as I can.  But all of a sudden I am more depressed then since my initial diagnosis.  Is this normal, shouldn't I just be grateful to be alive?   Janet Hello Janet,  I am sorry you are depressed.  It is alright to feel that way, but you need to tell your doctor.  You may need something to help you through this difficult part of your recovery.  I hate that I am not as physical as I was before, I hate I have gained weight, and I have good and bad days with depression. I went through most of what you went through and I have been taking the Femara for almost a year.  Th pain in my right hand is really bad at times, and I have it in my other hand, knees, shoulders and ankles.  I constantly drop things, have a hard time opening bottles and lifting things.  Sweeping, lifting a pot, trying to support a coffee cup can become a real chore.  I can't peel things anymore without lots of pain. I hate being this way, but I just have a good cry and push on.  I make myself get up and get moving.  I work at home, a lot, but I do go into the office on a regular basis.  I am sure your feelings are normal, but be sure you keep your doctor informed.  Best of luck to you!  Ann
Posts.Title: After math

Posts.Content: Most of us that have had breast Cancer and have been through the roller coaster ride of all the  surgery, chemo, radiation and drips understand the dread of another bump or lump appearing.  My greatest fear happened two weeks ago.  However, it did not feel or look like the lump I had before.  My cancer doctor looked at it and decided I should have a mammogram and sonigram to make sure it was not anything.  I had the tests and talked to the doctor that read the results. He said he had not seen anything like this lump.  He said it is not like any Cancer he has seen before, but the last lump was not supposed to be Cancer either and it was.  Because of my history, they are going to do a biopsy soon. Please, pray for me.  I have tried to be a positive person through most of  the treatments the last two years.  This time it has hit me really hard, and I am worried. Ann
Posts.Title: another lump

Posts.Content: On 5/16/2009 Leemg wrote: Sounds hopefull.  Glad to hear our doctors are taking that extra measure to insure things are okay.  My ultrasound is actually this coming Wed., the 20th.  I had it in my mind it was last Wed., went so much to get up and showered and on my way which is an hour drive only to realize I had the wrong day.  I've got too much of this going on in my life.  I need my own personal medical secretary, funny that is what I actually do for a living.  Well again, best of luck.  My surgeon also felt it had more to do with the surgeries that I have had but my plastic surgeon felt it is better to be safe and investigate further than do a wait and see.  I agree!  Take care Ann and keep my posted.  I'll do the same.  Maybe we will both come out with good results. I most certainly will keep you posted.  You do the same.  I laughed when you said you were on your way to your appointment and realized you had the wrong day.  I can't tell you how many times I have done this.  I keep two appointment books to keep me on track.  I think the worry makes us forgetful. Ann
Posts.Title: another lump

Posts.Content: On 5/8/2009 Leeanne wrote: I am a 46 year old who was misdiagnosed in 2006 with invasive BC Stage 2 node negative, I had pain and a lump of 3cm which was not seen on mammo was picked up on ultrasound but only as dense tissue, not cancer..Lump was removed due to the size but doctors showed no concern until after biopsy....Didnt clear margins so needed follow up surgery and node removal...Chemo and Radiation followed...My last few mammo's have shown distortion on Mammo and it always says MORE THAN LIKELY due to surgery changes, my recent mammo has shown calcification in an area that causes me pain and where lump was removed, the results were again POSSIBLY due to surgery....it's always more than likely or possibly never a definate answer.....Would appreciate a few more opinions on what you would do in my situation..... Thanks Leeanne Hi Leeanne, I had back to back surgeries, also.  I had a lump and the regular node removal as standard, I think five nodes.  After lump and nodes were sent off for evaluation, one of the nodes had a small tumor.  I had surgery to remove the rest of the nodes under that arm.  I was diagnosed with invasive BC, stage two.  I went through all the chemo and radiation treatments. I am not sure if you are asking about pain or distortion on the mamo's or both or if what they are saying is correct.  I have  tenderness and pain in the breast where I had surgery .  The doctors say it is from the radiation as I had 34 treatments.   I don't know about the distortion on the mamo.  I have never heard of that type of an explanation, but it could most certainly be correct.  However, I would definitely seek a second opinion as to what is going on.  Good luck, Ann
Posts.Title: Mammo and ultrasound showed up normal.....

Posts.Content: On 5/4/2009 Leemg wrote: You are not alone.  After having a clear mammo and MRI this past Feb. my OB/GYN felt something of "concern".  I have an appointment with my surgeon early this afternoon actually.  It has been 5 years for me with stage 1.  I'll be thinking of you as well.  I also had thyroid cancer which I'm monitored for and have a benign tumor in my inner ear which a surgeon suggests having out.  Never a dull moment as they say.  I say dull would be nice. Thank you everyone for your messages and prayers.  I was really down in the dumps, but I see the breast surgeon this Wednesday for consult.  I had assumed I would have been scheduled for the biopsy before now.  We'll see what happens.  I don't have the same feelings about this lump as I had with the last one.  I am going to be positive and believe it is not cancer this time.  Ann
Posts.Title: another lump

Posts.Content: On 5/16/2009 Leemg wrote: Sounds hopefull.  Glad to hear our doctors are taking that extra measure to insure things are okay.  My ultrasound is actually this coming Wed., the 20th.  I had it in my mind it was last Wed., went so much to get up and showered and on my way which is an hour drive only to realize I had the wrong day.  I've got too much of this going on in my life.  I need my own personal medical secretary, funny that is what I actually do for a living.  Well again, best of luck.  My surgeon also felt it had more to do with the surgeries that I have had but my plastic surgeon felt it is better to be safe and investigate further than do a wait and see.  I agree!  Take care Ann and keep my posted.  I'll do the same.  Maybe we will both come out with good results. I most certainly will keep you posted.  You do the same.  I laughed when you said you were on your way to your appointment and realized you had the wrong day.  I can't tell you how many times I have done this.  I keep two appointment books to keep me on track.  I think the worry makes us forgetful. Ann
Posts.Title: another lump

Posts.Content: Breast surgeon does not think it is cancer, but she said I fooled her once and she will not take a chance a second time.  I am scheduled for a breast MRI next Friday and will have a biopsy if it shows suspicious  and even if it does not, they are going to do a biopsy to make sure.  I just will not have to be in a hurry. Thank you, again for your kind words, and I will be thinking of you that are going through tests. Ann
Posts.Title: another lump

Posts.Content: I do pray for God's help, Filipina.  In fact, I am sure I would not be here if it had not been for prayers.  Thank you for responding. Ann
Posts.Title: no energy months after chemo

Posts.Content: I finished up chemo, radiation and my final herceptin drip 12/31/08.  I developed some pain in my joints, along with some other problems I never had before.  I was hoping after all this time, that my strength would be returning.  I still sleep a lot, and it is hard to get up in the morning.  I am taking 325 mg of iron three times daily along with one tablet of a chemo called Famara,daily.  I have some other med's I have to take daily, but they have never bothered me before.  They did increase my blood pressure medicine 10 mgs.  I try to walk everyday for twenty minutes as doctor recommended, but if I wait until afternoon, I can't do it.  I seem to have two to four hours of exhaustion mid-day.  I make myself get up, but I am so droopy and draggy, I drop and stumble.  I hate to compain as I am lucky to be alive, but is anyone experiencing this same thing?  Does it get better? Ann
Posts.Title: no energy months after chemo

Posts.Content: On 2/21/2009 trehouse60 wrote: Do what you can when you can, and otherwise heed your body's signals that it needs to rest.  Even though it seems like it's been a long time, it really hasn't.  Chemo can take up to 8 to 9 months to clear from the body, plus you've had the onslaught of other things. Your iron supplement probably isn't doing you much good.  The human body can only really absorb about 18 mg of supplemental iron a day.  Much better to try eating foods that are rich in iron PLUS a lot of other elements, such as antioxidants, the B vitamins, vitamins C, D and E.  Lots of calcium and other trace minerals.  The closer you can get to a vegetarian diet, the more likely you are to be eating foods that will provide the essential nutrients that have been bleached out of your body by all the treatments. Also important to make sure you're drinking plenty of fresh  pure water.  Hydration is key to rebuilding the blood stream and immune system, as well as detoxification of all the by-products of chemo and cancer cell death. Unless you are on a blood thinner, green and black tea are excellent choices for detoxification - get decaf, so that you aren't peeing out all the fluids when you drink. Eat plenty of fruit - an apple a day, any kind of berries (avoid pomegranate if you had hormone positive cancer,) citrus fruits and tomatoes.  Avoid bananas - they have way too much sugar in them.  Green leafy veggies, cruciferous veggies, and legumes (whole grains and beans) are vital.  Eat as much organic raw fresh foods as you can. Also make sure you are getting enough essential fatty acids.  Many people recommend flax seed oil or fish oil, but I think those need to be used with caution.  Flax seed oil is very high in phytoestrogens - if you had a hormone positive cancer, this might not be a good choice.  I'm also concerned about fish oil because of the extreme pollution in all of earth's bodies of water.  Roasted pumpking seeds are a delicious, nutritious alternative - a handful a day will provide ALL the omega fatty acids an adult needs per day, plus 14 gm plant protein.  I have a recipe for roasting green pumpkin seeds on my blog:  http://motherearthtreasurechest.blogspot.com/search?q=pumpkin+seeds There are also articles on the B vitamins, vitamin c, supplements, etc, etc, etc.  Please feel to read anything that interests you.  Take a look at the recipe for lemon volcano drink (enter that in the blog search box to get that article.)  It is really nutricious and an EXCELLENT detoxifier. Sincerely, Tre Thank you for your advise.  I will print it out and try some of the things you suggested.  Some of them I am already doing.  I am interested in the Lemon Volcano drink. I am hormone positive.  That is why I was able to take the herceptin drip for a year. I wonder why my occologist would tell me to take that much iron if it was not going to do any good? Thank you again for responding. Ann
Posts.Title: no energy months after chemo

Posts.Content: On 3/5/2009 carolyn97222 wrote:   On 2/20/2009 cacann wrote: I finished up chemo, radiation and my final herceptin drip 12/31/08.  I developed some pain in my joints, along with some other problems I never had before.  I was hoping after all this time, that my strength would be returning.  I still sleep a lot, and it is hard to get up in the morning.  I am taking 325 mg of iron three times daily along with one tablet of a chemo called Famara,daily.  I have some other med's I have to take daily, but they have never bothered me before.  They did increase my blood pressure medicine 10 mgs.  I try to walk everyday for twenty minutes as doctor recommended, but if I wait until afternoon, I can't do it.  I seem to have two to four hours of exhaustion mid-day.  I make myself get up, but I am so droopy and draggy, I drop and stumble.  I hate to compain as I am lucky to be alive, but is anyone experiencing this same thing?  Does it get better? Ann It took me about 5 months to start regaining my energy and strength back.  So hang in there. Also, Femara isn't a chemo drug - it's a hormone suppressor.   It has been known to have a lot of severe effects including fatigue for over 32% of the women taking it.  II have been on it for a month now, and so far I have no side effects.  Side effects can start up months after you start on it.  For some women the side effects are so severe that they stop taking it even though they know it's prolonging their life. Talk to your doctor about the fatigue because it's hard to know whether it's the chemo or the Femara.  Carolyn Carolyn, Thank you for responding.  I did not know Femara was a hormone suppressor.   Now, I understand a little more of what is going on.  I was sure the doctor called it chemo tablets.  No other doctor has ever corrected me when I told them what I was taking.  I did see my regular doctor this week.  He said my blood count is still a little low, and I have some thyroid issues, now.  This explains the extreme fatigue. Ann
Posts.Title: no energy months after chemo

Posts.Content: On 2/21/2009 Bonniee wrote: One of my friends said it took two months after her chemo to get her energy level back up again. She had to walk with a cane and use the little "motorized shopping carts" at the store. Her energy came back. Hang in there! Blessings, Bonnie Thank you, Bonniee.
Posts.Title: no energy months after chemo

Posts.Content: On 10/26/2008 FlyGirlDonna wrote: Is anyone else getting bone pain from their Meds? And what are you doing to elevate the pain? Thanks Donna Hi Donna, I am currently experiencing bone pain in several of my joints and expecially in my hands.  I am on Femara and an every three week herceptin drip.  My doctor seems to think it might be the herceptin drip as it is a stong dose.  He wants me to start having a weekly dose of this drug.  However, I went to a web site called www.askapatient.com and put in the Femara drug (chemo tablets)  and found all kinds of individuals experiencing the same joint pains I am having.  I believe it is the Femara, but will try the weekly dose of herceptin and see if it helps. If this does not work, alternatives are changing my chemo meds to a less effective drug or going on joint medication.  All I need is one more drug!  I also had terrible joint pain with my initial drip chemo treatments, but the pain went away when I finished the chemo cycles and started the radiation treatments. One of the things I am doing to help the pain is water arobics.  It has really helped my knee pain. Good Luck! CAC
Posts.Title: Bone pain

Posts.Content: On 11/2/2008 FlyGirlDonna wrote: CAC, Sorry to hear about your pain. Doesn't this just suck! I'm on a study drug called Sutent (antiangeogenisis drug). In the last month I have been out of bed maybe 7 times because of the pain. Now they have lowered the dosage and given me pain pills. Swell. Hey, if it works.....what can you do. I haven't had my scans yet but I had a lump on my rib the size of a golf ball and now it is the size of a pea. That is in just 1 month. Hopefully with the lower dose the pain will subside. I was on Famera for 5 years and it kept everything in check so I know it works but if the pain is too great for you there are many alternatives. Good luck, D Wow, D, Sounds like you have some serious joint pain.  Mine seems minor next to your pain.  I hope you are doing better, now.  I am still having some difficulities with my knees, hands and some other joints.  Sometimes, they are more painful than usual, especially if it is raining, but I am able to function.  I try hard to get up each day, dress and accompolish something, either cleaning or reading company reports or whatever. Take Care,  CAC
